column9: Comments

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: One fine summers day a group of people took to the bog for a day of turf cutting. Families and neighbours, both young and old, are seen carrying out traditional ways of working together and having plenty of craic into the bargain. Digging, spreading, reciting poetry, singing and even bread making are captured on camera. Filmed by Brendan Leonard. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zVTl7bSprVM" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: Bobby Thompson recalls American soldiers constructing portable Bailey Bridges across the Claddagh River during the Second World War as part of their training for the D-Day Normandy landings. The river below the bridge was also the annual spawning grounds of large migrating trout from Lower Lough Erne, and was known locally as the "reds" due to the crimson colour of the water caused by the large numbers of eggs they laid in the gravel beds. Recorded by young volunteers and edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Bobby Thompson American Troops Training at Claddagh Bridge

column9: Lisgoole Abbey is a large Georgian house on the shore of Upper Lough Erne with a battlement tower at one end. It has substantial grounds along the banks  of the Sillees River and was once a monastic site built in the 12th century. The abbey was burned down in 1360 and then restored and taken over by the Franciscan order in 1583. The Irish historian and scholar Mícheál Ó Cléirigh stopped there in 1631 while compiling the Book of Invasions and the Annals of the Four Masters which is an iconic history of Ireland and the most extensive compilation of the ancient annals. In the early 17th century there was a period of massive upheaval in Ireland which included the Flight of the Earls in 1607 and consequently the Irish Franciscans began to reassemble the documentary evidence of Ireland’s history from prehistory to 1616 AD. The work influenced the writing of national history from the 17th century onwards and its importance increased when the annals were edited and published in seven volumes between 1848 and 1851 by the great scholar John O’Donovan.

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: A group of men gathered to demonstate how to make a ruck of hay for the video camera. Friends Jimmy Magee, Francie Doherty, Pat McHugh, Patsy McElhill and others worked all day to build a ruck and make the hay ropes to tie it down. Jimmy also shows how to make a range of crosses made from rushes. Film by Brendan Leonard. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MyKrqWIdVTo" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: Eddie Brogan describes bronze smelting and moulding processes and reflects on the ingenuity of our bronze age ancestors from long ago who may have made the sword and axe head found nearby along the Arney River. The bellows used by Eddie were originally located in the forge at the Buttermarket in Enniskillen, and were then subsequently owned by Paddy Clancy who had a forge near Lough Lattoone. The forge was built by Eddie and when he opens its doors a crowd is sure to gather to trade chat. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/t8AEmmKF0fE" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column4: Artist TP Flanagan's Poem "On Arney Bridge"
column9: As a young man the Fermanagh artist TP Flanagan wrote a poem entitled "On Arney Bridge". The poem was carved on a limestone seat next to the bridge by stonemason Michael Hoy. Arney Bridge is believed to be one of the oldest plantation bridges in Ulster dating from the 1620’s. It carried the main coach road to Dublin and is a unique and rare example of its kind. Filmed and edited by Julian Fowler.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/oBI_0CKYOG8" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: There are many important sites in the area which show traces of stone-working from earliest times. The work of local field workers Gabriel Burns and Jim Nolan led to the discovery of many rock carvings which have now been classified as Atlantic Rock Art, particularly in the Marlbank and Cuilcagh areas. These finds, along with traces of megalithic tombs, early field patterns, cashels and raths show that these highland areas were extensively populated and cultivated from earliest times, some examples of which can easily be seen at the Killykeeghan Nature Reserve and Clyhannagh. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew. Photo by Jim Nolan.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ayzaSXQPs6s" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: This documentary film tells the story of a one year project by Cleenish and Killesher Community Development Associations which explored the culture, history and heritage of the area. It focused on the landscape archaeology of the site of the Battle of the Ford of the Biscuits at the start of the Nine Years War in Ireland, traditional brick-making and the restoration of Arney bridge – now thought to be one of the oldest in Ulster. The film features interviews with local people, professional archaeologists and brick makers, as well as Prof Henry Glassie who revisited the area in July 2014.
column10:
"

Battles Bricks and Bridges Vimeo from Marginal Voices on Vimeo.

"

column9: During the Second World War a French newspaper carried a story about a skirmish between Britain and the Irish Republic on the Cavan and Fermanagh border over flour smuggling. Hundreds took part and fields were turned white with spilt contraband. Harold Johnston tells the story. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Battles Bricks and Bridges Vimeo from Marginal Voices on Vimeo.

column4: Battle Of The Ford Of The Biscuits
column9: The Battle of the Ford of the Biscuits was fought at a ford on the Arney River at Sessiagh/Clontymullan in August 1594. Local Ulster chieftains led by Hugh Maguire clashed with English forces who were marching from Dublin to relieve the garrison at Enniskillen Castle. The battle was the first major engagement of what became known as the Nine Years War when Gaelic nobility opposed the extension of Elizabethan Crown authority into Ulster. This struggle was a seminal event in British and Irish history as the subsequent defeat of the Gaelic Lords led to the Flight of the Earls in 1607, and the Plantation of Ulster under King James I which has had an enduring effect to this day. The name of the battle refers to the spilling open of barrels containing hard baked biscuits which floated down the river. The biscuits were part of the provisions being brought for the garrison in Enniskillen. Paul Logue describes how the site of the battle was located. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew. Image Historic Environment Division
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/AWRaZRNWz-c" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>
column13: Change to Paul Logue and put this film in a seperate page

column3: At home and on the land
column9: This popular local trail along the shoreline of Upper Lough Erne affords the walker an opportunity to experience the sights and sounds of wildlife along the waters edge. On this occasion another more familiar group of animals was attracted to the microphone. Recording by Angel Grandi.
column10: Sound Ark · Sheep Flock Close

column9: When WW1 broke out Redmond urged young men to join the British Army whilst Sinn Fein called for a boycott on recruitment. Home rule was the dominant issue at the time and the Nationalist community was divided. The 1916 Rising, the War of Independence and Civil War exasperated divisions further. Ballymenone split, its band ripped apart and its instruments taken by pro-treaty members, known locally as the Molly Maguires. A group of young men decided to start a football team to bring both sides together as an act of healing. Mr Boyle in Passing The Time in Ballymenone remembers: "The Belnaleck Art McMurroughs they're called. We took in fellows from both ends do you see, from the Rossdoney end and the Back Road end and all, and we got up a great football team that is still going to the present day".

Also known as Binn Mountain, Benaughlin hill is easily recognisable in the landscape with its sharp outlines and rocky outcrops. It is steeped in legend. Donn Bin Maguire was a local chieftain who is said to have been lured to an underground lair under the hill by a white horse spirit, and he in turn carried off many people to live with him there. The image of a white horse is said to be an identifable feature on the east facing limestone cliff. White horses were also part of ancient inauguration ceremonies and the name Benaughlin is the anglizisation of "Bin Eachlabrhra" which means the Peak of the Speaking Horse. Binn was also known for its rich crop of wild bilberries. "Bilberry Sunday was held on the last day of July and was mainly a young people’s day. Bilberries were usually eaten on the spot, and if the crop was good cans of them were brought down for those at home who could not go up. There was much dancing, fiddling, wrestling and fighting. The cake women and fruit sellers would come out of town the night before and there would be loads of whiskey and poteen. Crowds would come up. There would be much match making at or after it." David Gamble, Lanaghran, Letterbreen 1 December 1942. Irish Folklore Commission Vol #891 pages 412-3.

Older local people sometimes speak in a jocular way about the dangers of going "Beyond the Arney" as if it were a place apart and with a meaning similar to that of going "Beyond the Pale". The origins of this expression may have some sound historical basis as the Arney River was a natural boundary in the early Christian period between the Kingdoms of Airgialla and Brefni. Today the river is the diocesan boundary between Clogher and Kilmore whose later boundaries mirrored exactly the extent of these ancient overlordships. During the Rebellion of 1641 a decree was made by Rory Maguire to make the Arney River the front line in the uprising in Fermanagh. "...I do hereby, straitly charge and command all manner of persons, of what rank, quality, or condition whatsoever they be, of the Irish nation, in this country, not to visit, confer, talk, or parley to, or with, any persons or persons, of, in or belonging to the garrison of Enniskillen, upon pain of death, and to forfeiting all the goods and chattels belonging to such offender or offenders, and likewise that none of the inhabitants of this country, on the west side of Lough Erne, live, dwell, or inhabit any nearer to Enniskillen, than the river of Arny, until further directions be given to the contrary, upon pain of the aforesaid forfeiture and penalty". (Signed.) RORY MAGUIRE. History of Enniskillen. W. Copeland Trimble. 1919.

Gaby Burns and Jim Nolan have spent over thirty years exploring and deep mapping the rocky limestone uplands of the Cuilcagh/Marlbank and Cavan/Burren areas for evidence of our prehistoric ancestors. Atlantic rock art, settlements, field systems, enclosures, boulder monuments and rock sculpting were identified, surveyed and recorded, and many have subsequently been added to national heritage and monument records. Like antiquarians of old, the two men adopted scientific and multi-interdisciplinary approaches to their work and the passion and dedication they give to their quest on such a landscape scale through successive time periods is truly impressive. Gaby takes up the story about how they first identified a way to interpret man-mde adaptions to large natural boulders and then how they provided evidence that they had been altered and reworked by human hands. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/QdVlMcb3P60" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: Mobile shops provided a lifeline to people living in isolated parts of the Cuilcagh uplands, particulalry in winter. Roy Cathcart reflects on the importance of the mobile shop in keeping people up to date with news, events, births, deaths and marriages. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Roy Cathcart - Bringing The News To The Community

column9: On top of Cuilcagh on its eastern edge is a large prehistoric cairn and probable passage tomb. It was constructed in order that it be seen from great distances. In the early nineteenth century the mountain's height and location also made it the ideal place from which to survey the surrounding countryside. Harold Johnston describes the important role that the mountain played in the 1830 Ordnance Survey of Ireland. He explains why the mountain was chosen, and describes the far away places and montain tops that can be seen across Ireland from its summit. He also touches on the origin of the word "limelight" and reflects on how you should never bring copper on to a mountain top. The trigonometry point placed on top of the cairn by army sappers still remains. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 7.9 Harold Johnston - Cuilcagh Mountain British Army Ordinance Survey 1830

column9: This short film records the sounds of the bellows and the flames in the clay furnace as bronze is made. A thoughtful production which is both a visual delight and restful viewing. A slow film which captures the process perfectly. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/B5A5yvcIWUk" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column4: Bronze Age Sword and Axe Head
column9: As little boys Maurice and Ambrose Owens found a sword at the stepping stones across the Arney River. They put it in a farmyard shed and forgot about it. Shortly after the river was dredged and stepping stones were removed. Fifty years later Maurice was prompted to search for it again after a community archaeolgy project suggested that the site of his find may have been an ancient routeway known as the Ford of the Strangers or Robbers, then the Ford of the Biscuits and in more recent times, the Mass Pass. The sword was identified as late bronze age - nearly 3000 years old. Another recent find of a bronze age axe head suggests that the crossing point may indeed have been an ancient routeway from Connaght into Ulster. Perhaps Cú Chulainn crossed the river at this point? Filmed and edited by Julian Fowler
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cgxaAkQXWZg" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: In 1790 the Earl of Enniskillen established a water powered factory on a stream in his demesne where his protégé Joseph Godber manufactured candlewicks from 1792 -1825. Initially, the material used was waste from the local cotton industry, but later, when cotton became unavailable, backings of flax were used to make linen candlewicks. There may have been candle manufacture on the same site as at one time there were “two tanks or boilers for melting tallow”. The water used to power the factory was channelled to a large mill pond by a long mill stream which snaked its way around the hill from Tully Mill just below where todays rectory is siuated. This entire complex including both mills was in turn fed by water from the Larganess River. Extract from Technology and the Big House in Ireland, C. 1800-c. 1930 by Charles john Thomas Carson. Research by Marion Maxwell.

The Arney River flows for eleven miles from Lower Lough MacNean to Upper Lough Erne. Fishing was an important activity but the water course deteriorated with the construction of the hydroelectric scheme at Ballyshannon and the lowering of the level of Lough Erne. Dredging of the River in the 1960’s had a further detrimental impact on fish stocks. However, travelling by canoe today down the slow meandering river is a wonderful way to appreciate its extensive natural heritage and beauty of the unflolding landscapes along its banks and beyond to the distant mountains. People in Glenfarne in County Leitrim often refer to their local river as the Upper Arney where it enters Upper Lough MacNean, which is apt when considered on a landscape and water catchment scale. Watch out for kingfishers, dippers and swans. Filmed and edited by Julian Fowler.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/v4d158Tm7wQ" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: The four McConnell brothers followed in the footsteps of their father Sandy by collecting and passing on the musical and songwriting tradition of the area. Cathal McConnell was a founder member of the Boys of the Lough and he published a major collection of one hundred and twenty-three songs in a book and CDs called "I Have Travelled this Country". He was also a major contributor to "Hidden Fermanagh" (2003) which was a further compilation of local traditional music and songs. The tune was recorded at the "Going Underground" concert in the Marble Arch Caves in September 2019. Recorded by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 2 - 2 CATHAL McCONNELL Buachaill Ón Éirne (Boy From The Erne) On B - Flat Flute

column9: John Kelly presents a fascinating story of what lies beneath our feet when we walk on Cuilcagh mountain. He describes the limestone geology and hydrology which combine to form the Marble Arch Caves. He hints too at the prospect that there may be more caves to be discovered and explored. He and other local cavers are still searching for the "big one" which they believe is waiting to be found.  If you see people digging holes on the mountain it may well be cavers trying to break through to hidden cave systems. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/TbQ8keG4y4s" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: The members of the Macken Vintage Corn Threshing Association gather at the house of Benny Solomon Maguire for a night of demonstrations on baking on an open fire and creel making, with flute music provided by John Joe Maguire at the end of the evening. Also featuring Jimmy Magee, Francie Doherty, and John Delaroma. Filmed by Brendan Leonard. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_snumnTCyhU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: St. Columbanus (540-615) is associated with Cleenish Island and is a major figure in early Christian European history. He founded a number of monasteries on the Continent including Bobbio in northern Italy. Indeed, many pilgrims and historians from Italy regularly visit Cleenish Island today. The island, where the young Columbanus studied under St. Sinnell, was the subject of an archaeological investigation in 2014 by a team from NUI Galway who discovered evidence of extensive occupation around the church site, and using radio carbon dating established that the skeleton of a decapitated man found at the site was killed and buried there in the sixth century. Little of the monastic site is visible above ground today as much of the cut stone was removed to build other structures in the area such as Nixon Hall. St. Columbanus continues to maintain his importance right up to the modern period, when Robert Schuman, one of the founders the modern European movement remarked in 1950 that Columbanus spoke of “a spiritual union between the principal European countries of his time.” As one of the first people to write of Europe as a united entity he is therefore sometimes referred to as the patron saint of Europe. Image: Irish Fieldschool of Prehistoric Archaeology.

Clontymullan Fort is located close to the site of the Battle of the Ford of the Biscuits on the Arney River. Nothing was known about it until a community archaelogy dig was undertaken in 2019 which found that the site had been occupied from about 1440 to 1550 by Turlough Maguire, a high status Gaelic Lord and his son Philip. They lived there in turbulent times with extensive raiding along the Arney River. The fort was sacked on at least two occasions as allegiences and power-play shifted between the Maguires, O'Neills and the O'Donnells. Archaelogist Paul Louge takes up the story. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/m-D6EdwC9EQ" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: This impressive 5000 year old neolithic dual court tomb is nineteen metres long. When constructed originally it had two entrances at either end which connected to a series of burial chambers. The semi-circular courts at both ends were delineated by upright stones and it is believed that these spaces were used for burial ceremonies. The side walls of the chambers were lined with upright stones and spanned with lintels and finally the monument was covered with stones to make a large rounded cairn. Visually, it would have been an impressive monument in the landscape and a statement about the importance of those buried within. As with similar monuments elsewhere the portable stone material was removed to build nearby walls and buildings and the contents of the burial chambers robbed out.

Brick making was a seasonal industry using local clay deposits along the Arney River and turf cut from local bogs which was used as fuel to fire the kilns. In Arney these clay deposits can be found just under the thin layer of top soil, some two feet down. Once fired in clamping kilns in the fields the bricks were transported on cots down the Arney River and Upper Lough Erne to Enniskillen where they were sold to building contractors. Brickmaking was a family and communal activity that provided much needed cash supplements to these rural farming communities. This film records how local people came together in 2014/15 to relearn the forgotten craft of traditional slap brick making in the way that their ancestors had done for hundreds of years before them. Filmed and edited by Julian Fowler.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/g7q3Dmf79e4" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: In 1959 a seventh century bronze-bound wooden trumpet was found in the River Erne opposite Cleenish Island. Simon and Maria O’Dwyer made two replicas of what subsequently became known as the Coolnashanton, or Erne Horn. Using these replicas they performed rarely heard early medieval music in the Going Underground concert at Marble Arch Caves. The sound and melodic notes from the horns create a chilling and memorable atmosphere. Recorded and edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Ancient Music Ireland - Lough Erne Horn

column9: Industrial activity in the area included the harvesting of bog cotton on Cuilcagh Mountain for making candlewicks and pillows at Claddagh Glen.The Irish parliament was eager to foster the new industry, granting bounties on the home sale of cotton in 1783. Unlike true cotton, the hairs of cotton grass lack tensile strength but despite this they were mixed with 25% wool or cotton and made into a fabric that was used in the manufacture of cloth, carpets and roofing felt. It was also used to stuff pillows, make candle wicks and as tinder to start fires.

column4: Cuilcagh to Cleenish: A Great Place
column9: Lisblake rath is about halfway between Cuilcagh Mountain and Cleenish island as the crow flies. It is an unusually large and impressive high status monument which was built to deter would be attackers in the early Christian period. It has deep double ditches and banks and is dated around 500-750 AD which was a time when local chieftains marked the boundaries of their territories with raths similar to this. It is also a good location on the Memory Map to locate our short celebratory film made for National Heritage Week 2020. The film showcases our area’s landscape and heritage from Cuilcagh Mountain to the shores of Upper Lough Erne. Made by a young film graduate the film draws on local knowledge to interpret the landscape, and combines stories, music, film footage and photographs of heritage project activities already undertaken by Cuilcagh to Cleenish, and contains interviews with people at selected heritage sites. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/G6F8fjzwuNA" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column4: Dawn Chorus at Florence Court Demesne
column9: At the end of May each year we have an opportunity to get up and out early to hear the bird song of the dawn chorus. These three recording were made in different locations in the grounds of Florence Court. The rise and fall of the chorus can be heard as it moves from awakening, to full chorus and then receding again. Recorded by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · International Dawn Chorus Day 2020

column9: In the Irish language 'Mullanaman' means 'the hill of the women' and is reputedly the site where local woman watched the nearby Battle of the Ford of the Biscuits in August 1594. Or could there be something else going on here? Archaelogist Paul Logue hints at an intriquing folk-memory and magical thinking from prehistory. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/q4YqIH8gBEw" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: This unusal neolithic or stone age court tomb and cairn was excavated by local antiquarian William Wakeman in the 1880's. He found fifteen cists, or small stone box-like burial chambers within the cairn mound indicating that the tomb was also used for burial in the later bronze age. The cairn has an unusual star shape which may be as a result of careless excavation and the removal of stones for local use. Image Historic Environment Division.

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: Patrick Murphy, Francie Doherty and Jimmy Magee demonstate how to thresh oats using flails. The two wooden rods of the flail were tied together with eel skins. Filmed by Brendan Leonard. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/1hsc_psZfTg" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: William Willoughby Cole (1807-1886) was the 3rd Earl of Enniskillen and was the Grand Master of the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland  from 1846 until his death. He founded the Florence Court Lodge and was a central figure in the Orange Lodges of County Fermanagh, and was a local figurehead for what became known as ‘Big House Unionism.’

column4: Foot Bridges Over The Arney River
column9: Bobby Thompson remembers how the Arney River was spanned at one time by three narrow pedestrian bridges which connected people living in communities on both sides of the Arney River, and which facilitated people from townlands around  Blunnick to access the railway halts on the Sligo /Leitrim and Northern Counties Railway line where they could board trains that ran between Enniskillen and Sligo. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 10.3 Bobby Thomston - Footbridges Over The Arney

column9: George Sheridan (1912-1998) was a local farmer who had a great interest in the folklore and culture of days gone by. His autobiography "When Turkeys Chewed Tobacco" (2001) recorded in great detail the lives of his family and neighbours in the uplands below Cuilcagh Mountain. He also recorded local stories for the Irish Folklore Commission. The book which was published after his death records a rural way of life which has now largely disappeared.

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: A group of young boys are shown the traditional way to tie stooks. Filmed by Brendan Leonard. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hOR_pny5dCw" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: In 1926 Mr Eddie Bracken from Coolnatreane townland found an object in a bog near to his home, and thinking it of some worth, he brought it to the editor of the Impartial Reporter who in turn sent it to the Belfast Municipal Museum. The object was identified as an invaluable Bronze Age gold lunula, or necklace. However, it was labeled as having been found in Cooltrain townland near Irvinestown and not Coolnatreane, and it was to be many years before a museum researcher, Mary Cahill, realised the mistake and this beautuful and unique object has subsequently been re-provenanced to its true find location along the Arney River. The lunula is beaten gold and is paper thin. It is worn by twisting it slightly to open it at the rear and then put around the neck. An impressive and high status object indeed. Photo Ulster Museum BELUM.A157.1926.view2-2113.tif
This film captures local craft making and farming practices demonstrated by people living around Belcoo and along the shores of Upper Lough MacNean. Produced by Belcoo Historical Society.
column10: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_HoE0sWFLB4" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>'

column9: Local people have childhood memories of carrying wood up to the top of Hanging Rock to build a pyre which was lit to celebrate the end of the Second World War. The tradition of lighing pyres on high places goes back centuries. Similar events in living memory celebrated the ending of World War One on Armistice Day in November 1918. The cliffs of Hanging Rock are the most striking feature of the Lower Lough Macnean Landscape. There is a legend about a man who was killed on the road below the cliff when a large boulder fell on him whilst transporting salt with a donkey and cart. No one has yet lifted the huge boulder to prove the story right or wrong. Nesting Peregrine Falcons are regular visitors to the cliffs where their distictive calls can clearly be heard. Recording by Angel Grandi.
column10: Sound Ark · Pilgrimage of the Peregrins

column9: In 2016 Henry Glassie returned to the area where he lived for seven years during the Troubles in the 1970's. Seamas McCannys' interview with Henry about his books which recorded the cultural and historical heritage of the people who lived in the area delights a local audience in a packed Arney Hall. The special welcome for Henry from local mummers at the start of the evening is an additional treat. Filmed by Development Media Workshop.
column10: <iframe title="vimeo-player" src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/99874472" width="400" height="225" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: The hydraulic ram at Florence Court House pumped water from the Larganess River to a tank in the house. It was called a "ram" as it made a sound like two rams banging their heads together. It ceased to work in 1964 when the house was supplied from the water mains. It was an inefficient way to pump water but it was free to run and easy to maintain. REcorded by Angel Grandi. In association with National Trust.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Hydraulic Ram Florence Court House

column4: "I wouldn't go down there if I was you!"
column9: Local story teller Seamas McCanny warns a group of people about the dangers of going underground by informing them what happened to those who ventured previously into the dark underworld of rivers, ghostly caverns, cold lakes and strange formations. However, what they found on this occaision was music and songs played by talented local people against a soft background of flowing water, whispers and echoes. Recorded at the Marble Arch Caves the "Going Underground" Concert showcased the area's musical and cultural heritage. Listen with headphones for best listening peasure. Recorded by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Going UNDERGROUND! - Marble Arch Caves Concert

column9: John McGourty from Marlbank worked as a young man on George Sheridan’s farm who was also a writer and local historian. McGourty relates his experience of growing up in this very remote upland area in his book We Lived with a Mountain (2003).

St. Lasair who gave her name to Killesher (Cill Lasair - Lasair’s church) is an obscure early Christian saint who is also associated with the parish of Aghavea (Brookeborough). Legend has it that she built the church at night and retired to her cell during the day. Apart from the ruins of the medieval church and graveyard in the townland of Killesher there is also ‘St. Lasair’s cell’ close by at Claddagh Glen. Photo Barney Devine.

This is an impressive portal tomb or dolmen, although its interpretation remains uncertain. It is located near a wall which was probably built of the stones robbed from the cairn surrounding the burial chamber. The 3D photogrammetry image gives an all round immersive picture of the monument. 3D image by Gaby Burns.
column10: Kilrooskagh Dolmen by gabyburns55 on Sketchfab

column9: As a young boy from Cork City, Myles Keogh spent his summer holidays with his uncle Robbie Lambe in a thatched cottage at Arney Bridge. He recalls a time of freedom and long days spent fishing, swimming and listening to the chat of nightly visitors to his uncle's fireside. He met his wife Kathleen during this period and both return regularly to Arney from their home in Galway. Recorded by Barney Devine. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Myles Keogh - Lambe's Academy

column9: The Land League reached Fermanagh in 1879, the year it was founded. In December that year the first meeting was held in Belcoo, and in March 1880 a second meeting was held in Enniskillen. However "On August 26th the first great public demonstration was held at Sessiagh, near Arney. Many priests were on the platform. A huge “Cead Mile Fáilte” banner hung over the lane to the meeting field, and green flags hung everywhere. One might think that it was a typical Nationalist day out. Strangely it was not. A quarter of the attendance was protestant. They now felt the the Orange Order had betrayed them and their Tenant Association was impotent. They came out of curiosity and went away impressed by the moderation of the Leagues organisation.” Fermanagh (1870-1900) Rev. Peadar Mac Doinnleibhe Clogher record Vol 5 No 1 (1963) pp 7-29.

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: The rural electricification scheme transformed the countryside and changed traditional domestic and farming practices for ever. Eddie Brogan was at the heart of this quiet revolution and he reflects on how it was received by people in the area and the changes it brought about, not all for the good. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 1. Eddie Brogan - Rural Electrification

column9: Florence Court House dates from the 1750's and is a popular tourist attraction. The house and estate had an extensive farm, gardens, and mills, and its location influenced the development of local industry and the road and rail network which served it. It was the home of the Earls of Enniskillen, who were the descendants of William Cole, the founder of the plantation town of Enniskillen. Turlough O'Carolan, the famous blind harper and composer (1630 - 1738) wrote this song for Mrs Cole. This version was played by the young harpist Shauneen Maguire in the Going Underground concert recorded in the Marble Arch Caves September 2019. Recorded by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 3 - 1 SHAUNEEN MAGUIRE Madam Cole

column9: The Brian Maguire chalice, 1739. Silver chalice with fleur de lys hallmark, probably French. Inscribed on foot “This chalice was given by Sir Bryan Maguire Knight of the Noble Ordre Militare of St Louis for the use of ye Convent of Lisgoole in ye County of Fermanagh, near Inniskilling, Anno domino 1739.” It was commissioned by Brian Maguire and gifted to Denis Maguire, Bishop of Kilmore (1770-1798) of the Franciscan’s of Lisgoole, Co Fermanagh. Brought to Manor Hamilton by the very rev. John Maguire, PP of Cloonclare (1866-1904) In the custody of Canon Michael Kelly, Manor Hamilton. Transferred by Bishop McKiernan, Bishop of Kilmore to Terence Maguire in June 1993. DM:2009.6, See file AI/09/156

column3: At Home and on the land
column9: Francie Doherty knows everything there is to know about working in a bog. His descriptions of a day spent cutting turf will evoke memories in many local people of days spent working communally with others in the local bog to bring home the turf for the winter fires. The advent of machine cut turf, oil fired central heating as well as environmenatal concerns has all but brought this tradition to an end throughout the country. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 3.1 Francie Doherty - A Day On The Bog

column9: "The lower end of  the parish had three Catholic bands - Sessiagh, Back Road, Rossdoney - and a Protestant band at Bellanaleck. There were also Protestant bands at Druminiskill and Florencecourt, and between six and eleven Catholic bands (accounts vary) between Arney  and the border. Once or twice a week and on certain Great Days too - Patrick's, the Twelfth of July, the Twelfth of August and the Fifteenth - bands swung along country lanes. If they met on the road, they beat competitively against each other for hours. "Man dear!" Joe Flanagan said. "It was great". (Henry Glassie: Passing the Time in Ballymenone).                                                                                                                                                    The Mullaghy Flute band was recorded at the "Going Underground" concert in Marble Arch Caves September 2019. Recorded and edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 6 - 1 MULLAGHY FLUTE BAND

column3: At Home and on the land
column9: John McNulty remembers growing up in Marlbank and he reflects on farming, church and school. Recorded by young volunteers and edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Marlbank Memories

column9: An unusual audio perspective on our natural heritage at Drumane Bridge. Recoding by Angel Grandi.
column10: Sound Ark · Ambient ASF-1 Under River Stream

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: Before the mass ownership of motor cars and the advent of supermarkets and convenience stores most people living in isolated rural areas were dependent on mobile shops for food and other essential items. As a young boy Roy Cathcart accompanied his father in his mobile shop on his weekly rounds to customers in the uplands around Cuilcagh. The shop carried just about every kind of basic commodity required by these farming communities. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 5.1 Roy Cathcart - "We Carried Everything"

column9: Martina O'Neill decribes the natural heritage that can be found in the Cuilcagh to Cleenish area. Taking us on an imaginative arial journey from mountain top to lough shore she presents a scene of different landscapes inhabited by a unique range of animals, birds, insects, trees, plants and fish.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="255" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/op3m3VzhY5c" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: Mumming has been practised in rural areas in Fermanagh for centuries. The syle of dress and content of mummers plays varied from place to place. John McNulty describes how mumming in Marlbank differed from elsewhere, and as a child remembers with great excitement hearing the troupe of mummers coming across the fields to his house. Recorded by Barney Devine. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Mumming On The Mountain.

column3: At Home and on the Land
column7: Jimmy Magee , Francie Doherty et al
column9: A group of local friends came together to film their well-honed traditional creel and mask making skills. Gathering at night to ceili, play music and have a bit of craic they also demonstrated their craft to the camera, behind which was the artful eye of local film maker Brendan Leonard. This is a truely delightful and remarkable production not only for the skills captured on film, but also for the easy cameradie and interplay between the group members This film evokes memories of a time gone by. Gone but not lost. Film by Brendan Leonard. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MXjv5l4Czlo" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: The Cathcart family was central to the life of Bellanaleck village where George ran the local shop and post office. His daughter and well known local historian Marion Maxwell reflects on her fathers values and role in local politics. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 9.2 Marion Maxwell - My Father

column9: Nixon Hall was an eighteenth-century mansion which was largely demolished in the middle of the nineteenth century. It is an intriguing site as little remains above ground other than some blocks of fine cut stone. Traces of several landscape features can still be identified on the surrounding hill tops. A traveller in the 1870’s mentions a brick-built house on the site but this was replaced soon after by a stone house which used dressed stones taken from the monastic site on Cleenish Island. Interestingly the house was accessible by boat from Lough Erne via a channel and Laragh Lough to the rear of the house. Marion Maxwell presents the rise and fall of this  short lived country mansion. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ejX8R_5BcUs" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: During the Troubles in the1970's, American anthropologist Prof. Henry Glassie lived for seven years in an area close to where the Arney River flows into Upper Lough Erne known as Ballymenone. He wrote about the people, history and culture of this part of rural Fermanagh. "Passing the Time in Ballymenone" and the "Stars of Ballymenone" are regarded as major contributions to Irish folklife and folklore in a time of great social and political upheaval.

column4: Rewriting History at the Red Meadow
column9: In 2014 two local community groups came together to find the disputed location of the Battle of the Ford of the Biscuits 1594. The site was variously said to be at Drumane Bridge, Arney Bridge or somewhere in between. Using community-led battlefield archaeology techniques and stories based on local folk memory recorded by Henry Glassie the project brought Queens University and Historic Environment Division into the fray. Based on ballistics found between Sessiagh and Clontymullan a determination on the site of the battle was finally made. Filmed and edited by Julian Fowler.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/OwPgg3R4Sag" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: Jimmy Magee, Francie Doherty, Frank Murphy and Benny Solomon Maguire gather to make a pike of hay. Using a twister to make the hay ropes they tie them around the pike to secure it. Filmed by Brendan Leonard. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Tb4pxr7sYVw" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: Sandy McConnell was a shopkeeper from Bellanaleck whose sons are renowned internationally as traditional singers and musicians. Sandy was a local recorder working for the Irish Folklore Commission (now the Folklore Department of University College Dublin) and the contribution that both he and George Sheridan made to folklore studies is immense.

The saw mill at Florence Court House is powered by a giant waterwheel that turns the circular saw blade through cogs and belts. The watermill is powered by water from the Larganess River and the saw was used to supply wod for the estate and surrounding area. Recorded by Angel Grandi. In association with the National Trust.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Saw Water Mill Florence Court Estate

column4: Saying The Hail Mary As Well As The Best Of Them
column9: Viola Wiggins recalls riding a horse to school and how her mother refused to have her children segregated for religious education. Recorded by young volunteers and edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 2.6 Viola Wiggins - Saying The Hail Mary As Good As The Best Of Them

column3: At Home and on the Land
column9: Francie Doherty, Frank Charles and Sandy Beatty give a master class on making a lazy bed using a loy. Easy chat accompanies the task. Filmed by Brendan Leonard. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/eww5SEYTCkI" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: Bulk ordering during the second world war takes on a new form in this story from Harold Johnston. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 7.5 Harold Johnston - Shrouds Across The Border

column9: In the early days of cave exploration a group of enthusiastic cavers from Queens University found more than they bargained for in a section of the Marble Arch Caves not open to the public. Harold Johnston tells a story of mischief and skullduggery. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 7.11 Harold Johnston - Skull Found At Grand Canyon

column9: High up over the bog at Aghatirourke a sky lark sings evoking memories of spring. Recorded by Angel Grandi.
column10: Sound Ark · Skylark Song, Aghatirourke

column4: Sligo Leitrim and Northern Counties Railway
column9: The Sligo Leitrim Railway and Northern Counties Line ran from Enniskillen to Sligo along the north side of the Arney River. Bobby Thompson remembers taking the train as a young boy and crossing over the Arney River on an old rickety pedestrian bridge from the railway halt at Abohill to his home in Blunnick. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi. Photo wiki.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Bobby Thompson First Journey On Sligo Leitrim Line

column9: Robert Harbinson (1928-2005) was sent to the area around Bellanaleck as a war-time teenage evacuee from Belfast. He celebrated his time in this part of rural Fermanagh during the Second World War in his wonderfully evocative and rustic memoir "Song of Erne". Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_I4Co99vtM4" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column9: Shannon Pot in County Cavan was traditionally regarded as the source of the River Shannon. However a recent experiment by John Kelly and local cavers showed that when coloured dye was put into a stream that went underground at Pigeon Pot near Gortalughney its coloured water subsequently emerged at Shannon Pot, indicating that the source of this mighty river rises in County Fermanagh. Filmed and edited by Andrew Khew.
column10: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dqkzp-SdUH8" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

column4: Stocious Pigs In A Horse And Trap
column9: Some people were very inventive indeed when it came to smuggling goods across the border between Blacklion and Belcoo. Viola Wiggins takes up the story. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Viola Wiggins - Stocious Pigs In A Horse And Trap

column9: Recording of voices and music TBC

The Storm of 1961 has gone down in history as one of the biggest hurricanes to strike the country with the result that there are many recollections about the damage it caused. This humourous story takes a lighter view of the Big Wind. Recorded by young volunteers. Edied by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Dereck Thornton - Storm Of 1961

column9: As a child growing up in Belanaleck the 12th of July was eagerly anticipated by Marion Maxwell. She recalls the preliminary preparations, feasting and the treats that were a big part of the day. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 9.5 Marion Maxwell - The 12th

column9: References to brick making along the Arney River are found in the Ordnance Survey Map and Memoirs of 1835 which show extensive brick fields peppered throughout several of the local townlands along the river from Rossdoney in the east to Derryhowlaght in the West, and on up to the old Florencecourt Tilery where better quality and standardised bricks, floor tiles, roof tiles, and drainage pipes were manufactured.

Tully corn mill and kiln are marked on the ordnance survey map of 1834 and are of special interest because of their technical features. The mill had a rare, and indeed one of the best surviving examples in Ulster, of a mill mechanism that transfered power from the wheel to the millstones as used in European water-driven grist mills from medieval times. The water wheel operated two sets of mill stones - one for shelling and the other for grinding - and its various sieves and fans were driven off pulleys fixed to pinions. A small seed house made of Arney brick was incorporated into the corner of the ground floor. Today this listed building has been lovingly preserved and converted into a restaurant by Killesher Community Development Association. Photo Barney Devine.
If you are unable to make it up to the wild mountain top the sound of this soft blustery wind on the slopes of Cuilcagh will take you there in your minds eye. Recorded and edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Sound Ark · Soft Blustery Wind

column9: The winter was a hard time for people living in the uplands around Cuilcagh. In a time before motor cars the mobile shop was often their only way of bulk buying for the long cold months. Some people even came over the border on foot to collect their groceries from the mobile shop. Recorded by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · Roy Cathcart - Winter Lifeline

column9: Our more recent past linked us to cataclysmic events in world history and left memories on the landscape such as the remains of houses on Cleenish Island which were built for a number of returning ex-servicemen after WW1. All but one of these houses now lie derelict. Their story is told in the award-winning Making It Home project by Bellanaleck Local History Group and the subsequent publication of the same name by Marion Maxwell and Fiona Wright (2017). Filmed and edited by Development Media Workshop.
column10: Making It Home from Marginal Voices on Vimeo.

column9: After the shipyards were bombed in Belfast during the Second World War many young children were evacuated to rural areas such as Fermanagh. Some came to live around Florence Court. Recording by young volunteers. Edited by Angel Grandi.
column10: Cuilcagh to Cleenish · 10.6 Bobby Thomston - WW2 Evacuees
